features.popup:
Kuyuidokado (Cui-ui Eaters)

Northern Paiute · Pyramid Lake · Kooyooe Tukadu
The Kuyuidokado — "those who eat cui-ui" — are the Northern Paiute band centered on Pyramid Lake, the largest remnant of Pleistocene Lake Lahontan. The cui-ui (Chasmistes cujus) is a large sucker fish found nowhere else on Earth, and its spring spawning run up the Truckee River was the most important food event of the year. Pyramid Lake also supported massive runs of Lahontan cutthroat trout — the largest inland trout in North America (up to 60 lbs). Their territory encompassed the Truckee River corridor from the Sierra foothills to the lake, the Lake Range, and portions of the Smoke Creek Desert. Chief Truckee (Tru-ki-zo) guided John C. Frémont across the desert in 1844. His grandson Chief Numaga ("The Generous One") initially counseled peace but led the Northern Paiute to victory at the First Battle of Pyramid Lake (1860) — one of the worst military defeats of settlers in the American West. His granddaughter Sarah Winnemucca became America's first published Native American woman author. The Pyramid Lake Reservation (est. 1859) is the oldest in Nevada and the tribe has never been fully relocated.
Key dates: 1844: Chief Truckee guides Frémont • 1859: Reservation established • 1860: Pyramid Lake War — Numaga defeats Major Ormsby (76 settlers killed) • 1905: Derby Dam diverts Truckee River, devastating fishery • 1967: Cui-ui listed as endangered • 2015: Tribal water rights settlement
Sources: Stewart 1939; Fowler & Liljeblad 1986 (HNAI); Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe; NV Indian Commission

Toidokado (Cattail Eaters)

Northern Paiute · Carson Sink / Stillwater Marsh · Fallon area
The Toidokado — "cattail-seed eaters" — occupied the Carson Sink and Stillwater Marsh, where the Carson River terminates in one of the richest wetland ecosystems in the Great Basin. Cattail (tule) was their primary food — seeds, pollen, shoots, and rhizomes were all consumed. The marshes also provided ducks (hunted with ingenious tule-reed decoys), fish, and other wetland resources. Their territory included the Lahontan Reservoir area, Stillwater Wildlife Refuge, and the desert playas south and east of Fallon. This area has extraordinary archaeological depth — Spirit Cave (10,600-year-old mummy), Hidden Cave, Grimes Point petroglyphs, and the Lovelock Culture type site are all in Toidokado territory. The Fallon Paiute-Shoshone Tribe represents their descendants today. In 2018, DNA analysis of the Spirit Cave mummy confirmed genetic continuity with the modern Fallon Paiute-Shoshone — 10,000+ years of continuous habitation.
Key dates: ~2000 BCE: Lovelock Culture flourishes in marshes • ~1000 CE: Northern Paiute arrive, absorb earlier peoples • 1908: Newlands Reclamation Project diverts Carson River, devastating marshes • 1990: Stillwater wetlands receive federal protection • 2018: Spirit Cave repatriation after DNA confirmation
Sources: Stewart 1939; Fowler & Liljeblad 1986; Fallon Paiute-Shoshone Tribe; Moreno-Mayar et al. 2018

Agai Dicutta (Trout Eaters)

Northern Paiute · Walker River / Walker Lake · Schurz area
The Agai Dicutta — "trout eaters" — centered their lives on Walker Lake and the Walker River, where Lahontan cutthroat trout and other fish provided the primary protein source. Their territory stretched from the Pine Grove Hills south along the Walker River to Walker Lake, including the Wassuk Range. The Walker River Paiute Reservation (est. 1874) near Schurz is their modern homeland. Every third weekend of September, the tribe hosts the Pine Nut Festival — a spiritual ceremony dating back over a century celebrating life and the pine nut harvest. During the pine nut dance, dancers move on sacred ground around the pine tree. Wovoka (Jack Wilson, c.1856–1932), founder of the Ghost Dance movement, was born near Walker Lake. His vision of a restored earth inspired one of the most widespread pan-Indian spiritual movements in history — and its suppression led directly to the Massacre at Wounded Knee (1890).
Key dates: 1874: Walker River Reservation established • 1889: Wovoka's vision — Ghost Dance begins near Walker Lake • 1890: Ghost Dance suppressed; Wounded Knee massacre • 1926: Walker Lake begins declining due to upstream diversions • 2019: Walker Lake Paiute Restoration Act proposed
Sources: Stewart 1939; Fowler & Liljeblad 1986; Walker River Paiute Tribe; Hittman 1990

Kucadikadi (Brine Fly Pupae Eaters)

Northern Paiute · Mono Lake / Bridgeport · CA-NV border
The Kucadikadi — "brine fly pupae eaters" — harvested the protein-rich larvae of the alkali fly (Ephydra hians) from the shores of Mono Lake, one of the oldest lakes in North America. These tiny pupae (kutsavi) were dried and traded as far as the San Joaquin Valley. Mark Twain described them in Roughing It. Their territory straddled the California-Nevada border, encompassing Mono Lake, Bridgeport Valley, and the eastern Sierra foothills. The Bridgeport Paiute Indian Colony represents their descendants. Mono Lake's ecosystem — and the Kucadikadi's ancestral food source — was nearly destroyed when Los Angeles diverted its feeder streams starting in 1941. A landmark 1994 court decision ordered partial restoration.
Key dates: 1941: LA begins diverting Mono Lake tributaries • 1978: Mono Lake Committee forms • 1994: State Water Board orders lake level restoration • Bridgeport Paiute Indian Colony federally recognized
Sources: Stewart 1939; Fowler & Liljeblad 1986; Steward 1933; Mono Lake Committee

Kamodokado (Hare Eaters)

Northern Paiute · Smoke Creek Desert / north of Pyramid Lake
The Kamodokado — "hare eaters" — occupied the harsh terrain north of Pyramid Lake, including the Smoke Creek Desert and Granite Creek Desert. Jackrabbits were their primary protein source, hunted in communal drives using long nets. Their territory extended to the edge of the Black Rock Desert — one of the most barren landscapes in Nevada, yet traversed for millennia by indigenous peoples following seasonal resources. The region contains some of the most remote and undisturbed archaeological sites in the Great Basin.
Key dates: ~1000 CE: Kamodokado band established in area • 1843-1868: Emigrant trail cuts through territory • 1860s: Conflicts with settlers and miners
Sources: Stewart 1939; Fowler & Liljeblad 1986; Steward 1938

Wadatoka (Wada Seed Eaters)

Northern Paiute · Humboldt Sink / Winnemucca / Lovelock
The Wadatoka — "wada seed eaters" — harvested seeds of the wada plant (Suaeda depressa, seepweed) from the alkali flats around the Humboldt Sink, where the Humboldt River disappears into the desert. Their territory encompassed the lower Humboldt River valley, the town of Lovelock, and surrounding ranges. The Lovelock Paiute Tribe and Winnemucca Indian Colony represent their descendants. This was a critical cultural landscape — the Humboldt Sink was the terminus of the most important river in the Great Basin, and the transition from Humboldt Sink to Forty Mile Desert was the most dreaded section of the California Trail for emigrants. Lovelock Cave, the type site for the pre-Numic Lovelock Culture, sits in their territory.
Key dates: ~1000 CE: Wadatoka replace/absorb Lovelock Culture peoples • 1845-1870: California Trail emigrants devastate resources • 1907: Lovelock Indian Colony established • 1917: Winnemucca Indian Colony established
Sources: Stewart 1939; Fowler & Liljeblad 1986; Lovelock Paiute Tribe; Loud & Harrington 1929

Summit Lake Paiute Tribe

Northern Paiute · Summit Lake · remote north-central Nevada
The Summit Lake Paiute occupy one of the most remote reservations in the United States, centered on Summit Lake — a natural lake at 5,900 feet in the high desert of Humboldt County. The lake is one of only two natural habitats for the Lahontan cutthroat trout (the other being Pyramid Lake). The tribe has been instrumental in preserving this species. Their territory encompasses the Jackson Mountains and surrounding desert valleys. Summit Lake is believed to have been a seasonal gathering site for Northern Paiute bands for thousands of years, situated at the crossroads of several band territories. The reservation was established in 1913 and covers about 10,800 acres. Despite its remoteness — over 60 miles of dirt road from the nearest town — the tribe maintains a strong cultural presence.
Key dates: 1913: Summit Lake Reservation established • Tribe federally recognized • Critical habitat for Lahontan cutthroat trout preservation
Sources: Stewart 1939; Summit Lake Paiute Tribe; U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service

Fort McDermitt Paiute-Shoshone

Northern Paiute & Western Shoshone · NV-OR border · Tagötöka & others
The Fort McDermitt reservation straddles the Nevada-Oregon border, home to both Northern Paiute and Western Shoshone peoples. The Paiute bands here include the Tagötöka ("biscuitroot eaters") who lived along the Owyhee and Quinn Rivers. Fort McDermitt was originally a U.S. Army outpost (1865-1889) established during the Snake War — one of the bloodiest conflicts in the American West. After the military abandoned the fort, Paiute and Shoshone families settled on the grounds. The reservation was formally established in 1936. The area was traditionally a meeting ground where Northern Paiute and Western Shoshone territories overlapped, and both languages are still spoken. The Quinn River and its tributaries provided critical water in this arid landscape.
Key dates: 1865: Fort McDermitt established during Snake War • 1868: Snake War ends • 1889: Fort abandoned • 1936: Reservation established • Mixed Paiute-Shoshone community
Sources: Stewart 1939; Inter-Tribal Council of Nevada; Fort McDermitt Paiute-Shoshone Tribe

Te-Moak Bands of Western Shoshone

Western Shoshone (Newe) · Elko / Battle Mountain / Wells / South Fork
The Te-Moak Bands are a confederation of four Western Shoshone bands in northeastern Nevada: Battle Mountain Band (Tonomudza/Donammuzi), Elko Band, South Fork Band, and Wells Band (Kuiyudika, "desert plant eaters"). Named after Chief Muchach Te-Moak, who negotiated with the U.S. government. Their territory encompassed the Humboldt River headwaters, Ruby Mountains, Jarbidge Mountains, and the vast valleys of northeastern Nevada — some of the most productive pine nut and game country in the Great Basin. The Te-Moak organized under the 1934 Indian Reorganization Act but traditionalists created the Sacred Lands Association (1974), arguing the Te-Moak council didn't represent them and that their land was never ceded. The Treaty of Ruby Valley (1863) is central to Western Shoshone identity — it granted passage rights but never ceded land. This became the longest-running land case in U.S. history (1962-2004).
Key dates: 1863: Treaty of Ruby Valley — peace and passage, NOT land cession • 1877: Duck Valley Reservation established — Te-Moak refuse to relocate • 1917-1918: Battle Mountain, Elko, Wells colonies established • 1938: Te-Moak Constitution adopted under IRA • 1962-2004: Longest land case in U.S. history • 2004: $145M award — many Shoshone refuse, insisting land not for sale
Sources: Steward 1938; Crum 1994; Te-Moak Tribe; Treaty of Ruby Valley 1863; ICC Docket 326-A

Central Western Shoshone (Reese River / Tonopah)

Western Shoshone (Newe) · Central Nevada · Yomba / Austin / Tonopah
The central Western Shoshone occupied the vast mountain-and-valley landscape of central Nevada — the Toiyabe, Toquima, Monitor, and Shoshone Ranges. This is the "Loneliest Road in America" (Highway 50) country. Band groups included the Reese River Shoshone near Austin and the Big Smoky Valley people. Their subsistence centered on pine nut harvesting (the most important food and social event), root digging, seed gathering, and communal rabbit and antelope drives. Family groups dispersed during lean seasons and gathered for communal hunts. The Yomba Shoshone Reservation (est. 1937) in Reese River Valley is the modern homeland for many of these bands. Sacred sites include Toquima Cave — a painted pictograph site high in the Toquima Mountains. The Western Shoshone made distinctive Brownware pottery and some bands practiced limited irrigation of wild seed plots.
Key dates: ~1000 CE: Western Shoshone arrive during Numic Spread • 1862: Silver discovered in Austin — miners flood territory • 1937: Yomba Reservation established in Reese River Valley • Toquima Cave preserved as sacred site
Sources: Steward 1938; Thomas 1983; Yomba Shoshone Tribe; USFS Humboldt-Toiyabe

Duckwater Shoshone Tribe

Western Shoshone (Newe) · Railroad Valley / Duckwater · Nye County
The Duckwater Shoshone occupy a reservation in Railroad Valley, one of the most isolated inhabited valleys in Nevada. Their ancestors lived throughout the White Pine and Nye County ranges, harvesting pine nuts, hunting antelope, and gathering seeds across a vast territory. The Duckwater Reservation was established in 1940 on land with natural warm springs — "Duckwater" comes from the wild ducks attracted to these springs. The tribe gained national recognition for their environmental stewardship: they earned the 2010 U.S. Fish & Wildlife Endangered Species Recovery Champion Award for restoring critical habitat of the Railroad Valley springfish — a tiny fish surviving in thermal springs since the Pleistocene, found nowhere else on Earth. The tribe has also been active in opposing nuclear waste storage at nearby Yucca Mountain and nuclear testing at the Nevada Test Site, which fell within traditional Shoshone territory.
Key dates: 1940: Duckwater Reservation established • 1951: Nevada Test Site opens on Shoshone land • 2010: Recovery Champion Award for springfish restoration • Opposition to Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository
Sources: Steward 1938; Duckwater Shoshone Tribe; USFWS; Inter-Tribal Council of Nevada

Ely Shoshone Tribe

Western Shoshone (Newe) · White Pine County · Steptoe Valley
The Ely Shoshone are Western Shoshone people in the Steptoe Valley and surrounding ranges of White Pine County. Their territory is a land of wide valleys between mountain ranges — the quintessential Basin and Range landscape. Pine nut groves in the Egan, Schell Creek, and Snake Ranges provided the most important food source. The Ely Colony was established in 1931 when the federal government purchased 10 acres for Shoshone families who had been living on the edges of the mining town of Ely. The tribe hosts the annual Ely Shoshone Fandango each July, featuring dancing, drummers, singers, and traditional events. Great Basin National Park — home to 5,000-year-old bristlecone pines, Lehman Caves, and Wheeler Peak — lies within their ancestral territory.
Key dates: 1868: White Pine mining boom brings settlers • 1931: Ely Colony established (10 acres) • Annual Ely Shoshone Fandango celebrates Newe traditions
Sources: Steward 1938; Ely Shoshone Tribe; Inter-Tribal Council of Nevada

Shoshone-Paiute Tribes of Duck Valley

Western Shoshone & Northern Paiute · Duck Valley · NV-ID border
The Duck Valley Reservation, straddling the Nevada-Idaho border, was the first and largest Western Shoshone reservation (est. 1877). The government intended to concentrate all Western Shoshone here, but most bands — especially the Te-Moak — refused to relocate from their ancestral territories. Northern Paiute from Oregon were then encouraged to join. Today it is a mixed Shoshone-Paiute community. The reservation covers 289,819 acres (453 sq mi) along the Owyhee River — one of the largest reservations in the western U.S. The Owyhee River provides irrigation for farming and ranching. Both Shoshone and Paiute languages and traditions are maintained. The annual Duck Valley Festival brings the community together each June.
Key dates: 1877: Duck Valley Reservation established by executive order • 1886: Northern Paiute begin joining Western Shoshone • Te-Moak bands refuse relocation • 289,819 acres — one of the largest reservations in western U.S.
Sources: Steward 1938; Crum 1994; Shoshone-Paiute Tribes of Duck Valley; BIA

Timbisha Shoshone Tribe

Western Shoshone (Newe) · Death Valley · CA-NV border · Koso/Panamint
The Timbisha Shoshone (also called Koso or Panamint Shoshone) have lived in Death Valley — the hottest, driest, lowest place in North America — for over 1,000 years. "Timbisha" means "rock paint" in their language, referring to the red ochre found in the valley. Despite the extreme environment, they thrived on a seasonal round: winter in the warm valley floor, summer in the cool Panamint Mountains gathering pine nuts. They harvested mesquite beans, hunted bighorn sheep, and managed resources across an elevation range from -282 feet (Badwater) to 11,049 feet (Telescope Peak). When Death Valley became a National Monument (1933), the Timbisha were nearly expelled from their homeland. The Timbisha Homeland Act (2000) finally granted them a 7,500-acre reservation within the park — making them the only tribe with a reservation inside a national park.
Key dates: 1849: Forty-niners cross Death Valley, naming it • 1933: Death Valley National Monument — Timbisha threatened with removal • 1994: Upgraded to National Park • 2000: Timbisha Homeland Act — 7,500-acre reservation within park
Sources: Steward 1938; Thomas 1983; Timbisha Shoshone Tribe; NPS Death Valley; Crum 1994

Las Vegas Paiute Tribe (Tudinu — Desert People)

Southern Paiute (Nuwuvi) · Las Vegas Valley · Snow Mountain
The Tudinu — "Desert People" — are the Southern Paiute band whose territory encompassed the Las Vegas Valley, Spring Mountains (including Mt. Charleston), and surrounding desert. "Las Vegas" is Spanish for "The Meadows," referring to the spring-fed oasis that the Tudinu had used for centuries. They practiced seasonal floodplain farming with irrigation for corn, squash, and beans — unusual among Great Basin peoples. Springs at the base of the Spring Mountains were sacred water sources. In 1911, rancher Helen J. Stewart sold 10 acres for $500 to be held in trust for the Paiutes — forming the original Las Vegas Colony in downtown Las Vegas. The tribe wasn't federally recognized until 1970. In 1983, 4,000 acres at Snow Mountain (between Mt. Charleston and the Sheep Range) were returned to the tribe. Today the Las Vegas Paiute operate the Las Vegas Paiute Golf Resort (three 18-hole courses, 4½ stars), the NuWu Cannabis Marketplace, and host the annual Snow Mountain Powwow.
Key dates: 1829: Spanish Trail opens through territory — devastating slave raids • 1855: Mormon missionaries establish Las Vegas Mission • 1911: Helen Stewart sells 10 acres for Paiute colony • 1970: Tribe federally recognized • 1983: Snow Mountain lands returned • 2017: NuWu Cannabis Marketplace opens
Sources: Kelly 1934; Kelly & Fowler 1986; Las Vegas Paiute Tribe; UNLV Nuwuvi History; NV Indian Commission

Moapa Band of Paiutes (Moapats)

Southern Paiute (Nuwuvi) · Muddy River / Virgin River · Moapa Valley
The Moapa (Moapats) occupied the confluence of the Muddy River (Moapa) and Virgin River in southeastern Nevada — one of the few areas with reliable year-round water in the southern Great Basin. They practiced irrigation agriculture before European contact, growing corn, squash, melons, gourds, sunflowers, beans, and wheat. This agricultural tradition connects them to the earlier Ancestral Puebloan (Anasazi) presence in the region — the "Lost City" (Pueblo Grande de Nevada) near Overton was occupied 300-1150 CE before being abandoned. Southern Paiute arrived ~1100 CE and may have absorbed remnant Puebloan populations. The Moapa Reservation was established in 1873 — originally intended to be the entire Moapa River watershed (39,000 sq mi), but was slashed to just 1,000 acres in 1875. Congress restored over 60,000 acres in 1980. Today the tribe operates the groundbreaking Moapa Southern Paiute Solar Project — 250 MW, the first large-scale solar project on tribal land in North America.
Key dates: ~300-1150 CE: Ancestral Puebloan "Lost City" occupied • ~1100 CE: Southern Paiute arrive • 1776: Dominguez-Escalante encounters Paiute • 1873: Reservation established (39,000 sq mi promised) • 1875: Reduced to 1,000 acres • 1980: 60,000+ acres restored • 2017: 250 MW solar project completed
Sources: Kelly 1934; Kelly & Fowler 1986; Moapa Band of Paiutes; Lost City Museum; Euler 1966

Pahrump Band of Paiutes

Southern Paiute (Nuwuvi) · Pahrump Valley · Nye County
The Pahrump Band occupied Pahrump Valley west of Las Vegas, named from the Southern Paiute word "Pah-Rimpi" meaning "water rock" or "water place," referring to the natural springs that made the valley habitable. These springs — fed by an aquifer recharged from the Spring Mountains — supported a small but sustained community. The Pahrump people cultivated small garden plots and gathered extensively from the surrounding desert and mountains. Their territory extended into the Amargosa Desert and parts of the Spring Mountains. Unlike the Las Vegas and Moapa bands, the Pahrump Paiute do not have a large federal reservation, but maintain their cultural identity as a distinct Southern Paiute band.
Key dates: Traditional territory centered on Pah-Rimpi springs • ~1100 CE: Southern Paiute arrive in area • Contact period: Mormon and mining impacts • Pahrump Band maintains cultural identity
Sources: Kelly 1934; Kelly & Fowler 1986; NV Indian Commission; Neon Museum Indigenous Peoples guide

Chemehuevi (Southern Paiute)

Southern Paiute (Nuwuvi) · Colorado River corridor · southernmost Nevada
The Chemehuevi are the westernmost band of the Southern Paiute, occupying territory along the Colorado River in the southernmost tip of Nevada, extending into California and Arizona. Their name may come from Mohave "Tcimiwavi" meaning "those who play with fish." They were semi-nomadic, ranging from the river to the mountains, and were expert runners — reportedly able to cover 100 miles in a day. The Chemehuevi had close (if sometimes tense) relations with the Mohave (Pipa Aha Macav), who lived along the Colorado River to the south. Spirit Mountain (Avi Kwa Ame), sacred to both peoples as a place of creation, dominates this landscape. In 2023, the surrounding 506,000 acres were designated Avi Kwa Ame National Monument.
Key dates: ~1100 CE: Chemehuevi expand into Colorado River corridor • 1776: Spanish contact • 1829-1848: Old Spanish Trail devastates through slave raids • 2023: Avi Kwa Ame National Monument designated (506,000 acres)
Sources: Kelly & Fowler 1986; Laird 1976; Avi Kwa Ame NM; Grapevine Canyon NRHP

Welmelti — Northern Washoe

Washoe (Washshiw) · Northern band · Honey Lake / Long Valley
The Welmelti ("northerners") were the northern division of the Washoe, ranging from Honey Lake and Long Valley in the north to the Truckee Meadows area. Their seasonal round took them to Lake Tahoe in summer for fishing and hunting, and east to the Pine Nut Range in fall for the pine nut harvest. The Welmelti had the most contact with Northern Paiute bands and some intermarriage occurred, though the two peoples spoke entirely different languages and had distinct cultural practices. The Reno-Sparks Indian Colony includes Washoe members alongside Northern Paiute and Shoshone.
Key dates: Ancient presence — possibly 6,000-9,000+ years • 1844: Frémont encounters Washoe • 1858: Honey Lake conflict with settlers • Reno-Sparks Indian Colony includes Welmelti descendants
Sources: d'Azevedo 1986 (HNAI); Price 1980; Nevers 1976; Washoe Tribe of NV & CA

Pau Wa Lu — Carson Valley Washoe

Washoe (Washshiw) · Central band · Carson Valley / Eagle Valley / Lake Tahoe
The Pau Wa Lu ("people of Carson Valley") occupied the heart of Washoe territory — Carson Valley, Eagle Valley (Carson City), Washoe Valley, and the eastern shores of Da ow aga (Lake Tahoe). "Tahoe" is an anglicization of the Washoe word Da ow meaning "the lake." The lake was the spiritual and physical center of Washoe life — summer fishing camps dotted its shores, and the spring spawning runs of Lahontan cutthroat trout up the Truckee River were a critical food event. Cave Rock (De ek wadapush) on the lake's east shore is the most sacred Washoe site — a power place where spiritual leaders sought visions. The Washoe are famous for their extraordinary basket weaving — Dat So La Lee (Louisa Keyser, 1829-1925) created masterworks now valued at over $1 million. The Washoe Tribe of Nevada and California was organized in 1934 and has offices in Gardnerville.
Key dates: ~4000+ BCE: Washoe presence at Lake Tahoe • ~500 CE: Kings Beach Complex (early Washoe culture) • 1848-63: Gold/silver rush devastates territory • 1857: Potato War — last armed Washoe conflict • 1917: Small land purchases near Carson City • 1934: Washoe Tribe recognized under IRA • 2002: Lake Tahoe cultural lands granted
Sources: d'Azevedo 1986; Price 1980; Nevers 1976; Washoe Tribe; Palisades Tahoe; Tallac Historic Site

Hung a Lel Ti — Southern Washoe

Washoe (Washshiw) · Southern band · Topaz Lake / Antelope Valley
The Hung a Lel Ti ("southerners") ranged from Topaz Lake and the upper West Walker River south through Antelope Valley to the Sonora Pass area. Their territory marked the southern boundary of the Washoe world, bordering Northern Paiute (Kucadikadi) and Miwok peoples to the south. Like all Washoe bands, they participated in the annual pine nut gathering in the Pine Nut Range — the most important social and spiritual event. The southern Washoe had more contact with trans-Sierra trade networks, exchanging goods with California peoples. Topaz Lake, one of the last reliable water bodies along the Walker River system, was a key fishing and gathering site.
Key dates: Ancient presence — Washoe linguistic isolation suggests 6,000+ year presence • Southern boundary of Washoe world • Contact with trans-Sierra trading networks
Sources: d'Azevedo 1986; Price 1980; Nevers 1976; Washoe Tribe of NV & CA

Fort Mojave Indian Tribe (Pipa Aha Macav)

Mojave · Colorado River · NV-AZ-CA tri-state · Yuman speakers
The Pipa Aha Macav ("people by the river") — the Mojave — are the fifth Great Basin tribe in Nevada, though culturally they are a Colorado River Yuman people, entirely distinct from the Numic-speaking Paiute and Shoshone. They are powerful river farmers who grew corn, beans, squash, and melons on the Colorado River floodplain. Their territory in Nevada is small — the southernmost tip along the Colorado River near Laughlin — but their cultural influence is vast. Avi Kwa Ame (Spirit Mountain), visible from their territory, is central to their creation story: the creator spirit Mastamho led the Mojave from Spirit Mountain to the Colorado River. The Fort Mojave Reservation spans Nevada, Arizona, and California. The tribe is known for their distinctive body tattooing, elaborate dream narratives, and the keruk (mourning ceremony). Unlike most Great Basin peoples, the Mojave had a tribal chief structure and fought organized battles.
Key dates: ~1200 CE: Mojave established on Colorado River • 1604: Spanish explorer Oñate encounters Mojave • 1858-59: Mojave War with U.S. Army • 1880: Fort Mojave Reservation established • 2023: Avi Kwa Ame National Monument designated
Sources: Kroeber 1925; Stewart 1983 (HNAI); Fort Mojave Indian Tribe; Avi Kwa Ame NM

📍 Pyramid Lake Reservation

Kuyuidokado (Northern Paiute) · Est. 1859 · 475,000 acres
Oldest reservation in Nevada. Encompasses all of Pyramid Lake. Home of the cui-ui and Lahontan cutthroat trout.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Walker River Reservation

Agai Dicutta (Northern Paiute) · Est. 1874 · 323,000 acres
Home of Wovoka and the Ghost Dance. Pine Nut Festival every September.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Fallon Paiute-Shoshone

Toidokado (Northern Paiute) & Shoshone · Est. 1908 · 8,200 acres
Near Spirit Cave, Hidden Cave, Grimes Point. 2018 DNA confirmed 10,000-year continuity.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Lovelock Colony

Wadatoka (Northern Paiute) · Est. 1907 · 20 acres
Near Lovelock Cave type site. Named after George Lovelock, not the archaeological culture.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Winnemucca Colony

Northern Paiute · Est. 1917 · 340 acres
Named after Chief Winnemucca. Sarah Winnemucca's ancestral territory.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Summit Lake Reservation

Northern Paiute · Est. 1913 · 10,800 acres
One of most remote reservations in U.S. Critical Lahontan cutthroat trout habitat.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Reno-Sparks Indian Colony

Paiute, Shoshone & Washoe · Est. 1917 · 1,920 acres
Multi-tribal urban colony. Hosts annual Numaga Powwow (Labor Day). Named for Chief Numaga.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Yerington Colony & Reserve

Northern Paiute · Est. 1917/1936 · 1,632 acres
Mason Valley. Campbell Ranch (1936) serves as main community.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Duck Valley Reservation

Shoshone-Paiute · Est. 1877 · 289,819 acres
Spans NV-ID border. First and largest Western Shoshone reservation. 453 sq mi along Owyhee River.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Te-Moak (Battle Mountain)

Western Shoshone (Tonomudza) · Est. 1917 · 683 acres
Battle Mountain Band. Refused relocation to Duck Valley.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Te-Moak (Elko Colony)

Western Shoshone · Est. 1918 · 193 acres
Hosts annual Elko Te-Moak Powwow in October — one of Nevada's largest.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Te-Moak (South Fork)

Western Shoshone · Est. 1941 · 13,050 acres
South Fork Band. Lee, Nevada. Largest Te-Moak land area.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Te-Moak (Wells Colony)

Western Shoshone (Kuiyudika) · Est. 1980 · 80 acres
Wells Band. Kuiyudika — "desert plant eaters." Clover Valley rendezvous site.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Duckwater Reservation

Western Shoshone · Est. 1940 · 3,815 acres
Railroad Valley. 2010 Recovery Champion Award for springfish restoration.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Yomba Reservation

Western Shoshone · Est. 1937 · 4,718 acres
Reese River Valley. Central Nevada's most isolated reservation.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Ely Colony

Western Shoshone · Est. 1931 · 100 acres
White Pine County. Annual Ely Shoshone Fandango each July.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Las Vegas Paiute Colony

Tudinu (Southern Paiute) · Est. 1911/1970 · 3,850 acres
Original 10 acres bought by Helen Stewart for $500. Snow Mountain (4,000 acres) returned 1983.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Moapa River Reservation

Moapa Band (Southern Paiute) · Est. 1873 · 71,954 acres
First large-scale solar project on tribal land (250 MW). Originally promised 39,000 sq mi.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Washoe Colony (Dresslerville)

Washoe (Pau Wa Lu) · Est. 1917 · 795 acres
Gardnerville area. Washoe Tribe headquarters. Named for Bill Dressler who sold land.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Washoe Colony (Stewart)

Washoe · Est. 1917 · 63 acres
Near Carson City. Stewart Indian School (1890-1980) — boarding school site, now museum.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites

📍 Washoe Colony (Woodfords)

Washoe (Hung a Lel Ti) · Est. 1917 · 80 acres
Alpine County, CA. Southernmost Washoe colony.

📍 Fort Mojave Reservation

Pipa Aha Macav (Mojave) · Est. 1880 · 32,000 acres
Spans NV-AZ-CA. Colorado River Yuman people. Creation site: Avi Kwa Ame.
Sources: NV Indian Commission; BIA; tribal websites
